listicle_content.listicle: May 21: India Today exposed that Maharashtra BJP leader Eknath Khadse was on the most dialled list of Dawood Ibrahim\'s international call list. Manish Bhangale, an ethical hacker in Vadodra, had given to India Today the call records of 4 phones registered in the name of Dawood\'s wife Mehjabeen Shaikh.

May 22: Khadse accepted that the telephone number in question was registered in his name but said he never spoke to the fugitive gangster or any of his family members. But the phone bills (021- 3587****) debunked Khadse\'s defence, provided exact call details and duration of conversations between Khadse and Dawood. Later, Maharashtra government ordered a probe into whether phone calls were made from the telephone number registered at the gangster\'s residence in Karachi.
May 25: Records show Khadse\'s wife Mandakini and son-in-law Girish Chaudhary bought 1.21 hectares of land in Bhosari, Pune, for a mere Rs 3.75 crore against the RR price of Rs 23 crore.
May 29: Land owner Abbas Ukani approached Khadse with a complaint that he should either be provided due compensation for the land acquisition or an alternate piece of land be allotted to him.

June 1: A new India Today sting nailed Khadse\'s lies. The sting revealed that Khadse left no stones unturned to intimidate and silence whistleblower Hemant Gawande, who had red-flagged the land grabbing by the minister. The report also showed a Pune Police inspector confirming that Khadse pressurised them to register a case against Gawande. While inspector Hiraman Shirsaat had then refused to oblige the minister, the Pune Police did in fact register a case against Gawande on January 31 last year finding nothing so far against the whistleblower.

June 4: With his position becoming untenable after the central leadership sent a clear and stern message, the 64-year-old veteran from north Maharashtra drove this morning to Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis\'s official residence to offer his resignation.

story.storykicker: Eknath Khadse is the first casualty in BJP since the Narendra Modi-Amit Shah combine took over pledging zero-tolerance towards corruption.
story.storybody:
Eknath Khadse, the revenue minister in the BJP-led government in Maharashtra, today submitted his resignation to Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis after India Today Television aired a series of investigative reports regarding the minister's links with notorious gangster Dawood Ibrahim and his involvement in multi-crore land scam.

Khadse is the first casualty in BJP since the Narendra Modi-Amit Shah combine took over pledging zero-tolerance towards corruption.

ALSO READ: Khadse pays price for overconfidence and bad company

How Khadse was nailed by Dawood calls and Pune land grab: A timeline

{funfacts}
  1. May 21: India Today exposed that Maharashtra BJP leader Eknath Khadse was on the most dialled list of Dawood Ibrahim's international call list. Manish Bhangale, an ethical hacker in Vadodra, had given to India Today the call records of 4 phones registered in the name of Dawood's wife Mehjabeen Shaikh.
  2. May 22: Khadse accepted that the telephone number in question was registered in his name but said he never spoke to the fugitive gangster or any of his family members. But the phone bills (021- 3587****) debunked Khadse's defence, provided exact call details and duration of conversations between Khadse and Dawood. Later, Maharashtra government ordered a probe into whether phone calls were made from the telephone number registered at the gangster's residence in Karachi.
  3. May 25: Records show Khadse's wife Mandakini and son-in-law Girish Chaudhary bought 1.21 hectares of land in Bhosari, Pune, for a mere Rs 3.75 crore against the RR price of Rs 23 crore.
  4. May 29: Land owner Abbas Ukani approached Khadse with a complaint that he should either be provided due compensation for the land acquisition or an alternate piece of land be allotted to him.
  5. June 1: A new India Today sting nailed Khadse's lies. The sting revealed that Khadse left no stones unturned to intimidate and silence whistleblower Hemant Gawande, who had red-flagged the land grabbing by the minister. The report also showed a Pune Police inspector confirming that Khadse pressurised them to register a case against Gawande. While inspector Hiraman Shirsaat had then refused to oblige the minister, the Pune Police did in fact register a case against Gawande on January 31 last year finding nothing so far against the whistleblower.
  6. June 4: With his position becoming untenable after the central leadership sent a clear and stern message, the 64-year-old veteran from north Maharashtra drove this morning to Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis's official residence to offer his resignation.
{funfacts}
